Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Sharp Neat bugs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=q_m31WeWTP7RzQ91H8tZCRGyV6kTLJOgeuaFg7yNbI_KNSILuKVN
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 18 February 2016 at 22:21, kstanley@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> Colin, for some reason I'm having trouble getting the PDF Pablo mentioned.
>  Can you review what the AddConnection() bugs were that you mentioned they could have an impact on performance?
>

I'll attempt an explanation to supplement Pablo's.

Firstly, note this issue relates to feed-forward mode only; SharpNEAT
version 2 has a switch to enable this mode but I don't know if this
switch is actually used much.

Ok so it's to do with random selection of source and target
neurons/nodes when adding a new connection.

The nodes are always ordered in a 1D array/list as follows:

   Bias | Inputs | Outputs | Hidden


So for a given experiment the number and positions of the first three
types of node are static for all genomes (hmm, in fact I could just
define that part of the genome in a single structure common to all
genomes; that's not occurred to me until now). Anyways...

Obviously the number of hidden nodes can grow, but basically when
choosing a random source node I generate a random number between zero
and  (total - outputs) - 1. And convert that into an index into the 1D
array to select a source node. But we need to not index the output
nodes which are in the middle of the array.

To address this issue I should have done:

   if(index > (biasCount + inputCount))
       index += outputCount;

But instead did:

   if(index > (biasCount + inputCount) && index < (biasCount +
inputCount + outputCount))
       index += outputCount;


(N.B. I'm just doing this from memory, so there might be some off by
one errors in the bounds tests there).


Meaning that if the random num was above the highest output node
index, the number was not shifted up as it should be, and so there was
a range of hidden nodes that could never be selected at the end of the
list, and some nodes that had a doubled probability of being selected.
The number of affected hidden nodes is (I think) the number of outputs
nodes, so the problem is worse if you have lots of output nodes.

On the target node selection there was a similar problem whereby the
node before the chosen source node could never be selected, so a
lesser problem, but definitely not great.

There were some  other issues in the spirit of absolute correctness of
evenly spreading out mutations - so of no major concern I don't think.

And then there was one where genomes are selected from the head of a
list (from each species), such that the same genomes are selected at
each generation if they all have the same fitness (e.g. zero). To mix
it up a bit I now randomize the order of genomes with the same fitness
level at each generation - I'm calling that a 'Perfectly Unstable
Sort' (a stable sort being one that preserves relative position of
items of equal value).

I guess that /could/ have a big affect on genetic diversity early on
in a simulation/run... but whether that has much of an effect
generally is hard to say.

 - Colin
